div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE STATE OF EUROPE
div.p: The conference of Algeciras has drawn attention to the possible assistance which Great Britain may render to France if events should happen to take an unfortunate turn. This goodwill which has sprung up in recent between France and England, of which President Loubet so felicitously indicated last week the origin and progress, is the sentiment accompanying a very important historical development. It indicates the instinctive recognition by both nations of Great Britain’s peculiar function in the Euro¬pean economy. The Continent of Europe contains a number of nations and of great States more or less identical with them. These States, in virtue of the principle of their existence, which is that of the independence of each of them, reinforced in modern times and especially in the last hundred years by the principle of nationality, and necessarily in perpetual rivalry, which leads to groupings that vary from time to time. The general prin¬ciple of the groupings has been, since the Six¬teenth Century at any rate, that in proportion as one State increases in population, territory, and organization, and therefore in power, the others become apprehensive of its too great preponderance. Its great prosperity and strength begin to seem a menace to the inde¬pendence of the others, and the growing State, in the consciousness of its developing power, is apt to expect its influence to become paramount and to attribute to itself a superiority hardly consistent with the fall autonomy of its neighbours. Such was the posi¬tion at one time of the Germania Empire, at another of the Spanish Monarchy, afterwards of the French Monarchy, and subsequently of the first French Empire. In every case the expanding State found the maritime power of Great Britain an obstacle to the foil attain¬ment of the sort of supremacy towards which it was impelled. There has, therefore, always been tendency for Great Britain to be regarded with special jealousy by the strongest Conti¬nental Power, and the consequence of that jealousy has always been to draw towards Great Britain the sympathy of those Continen¬tal States which were apprehensive of a prepon¬derance dangerous to their free will. The difficult periods have been those of transition, when there has been a change in the relations of the Continental Powers. Thus Great Britain in tie Sixteenth Century found herself in opposition to the preponderance of Spain. The sentiment of opposition lasted long after the necessity was gone, and the tendency to co-operate with France was continued into the period when the real danger to the independence of States was from France rather than from Spain.

During the second half of the Nineteenth Century the great change that took place in Europe was the attainment of German unity, and the rise in Central Europe of a German S ate stronger in respect of population, territory, and organization than any of the other settled States, for Russia is still rather an Asiatic despotism than a European organised State. The event of the dose of the Nineteenth Century was the propagation in Germany of the theory that Great Britain with her maritime resources and her colonies and her Indian Empire was an obstacle to Germany’s develop¬ment. This propaganda, sedulously fostered by an influential party in Germany, was ac¬companied by a corresponding development of German sentiment. The event of the beginning of the Nineteenth Century has been the recog-nition in England of the political significance of this new German sentiment Germany has taken the place in the European system which was occupied in the Sixteenth Century by the Spanish Monarchy and in the Seventeenth by he French Monarchy. It is of the expansive purpose of Germany that her neighbours are apprehensive, and at the same time Germany has shown that she regards Great Britain as it was regarded by Philip II., by Louis XIV., and by Napoleon. The recognition of these foots has made dear to the other Continental States the true position of England, obscured tor nearly a century They now see that England with her naval power is the balancing element in the European system, the one element which by its nature must be in sympathy with their independence and opposed to any designs which would menace it This is the funda¬mental fact, the instinctive recognition of which is the deep historical basis of the entente cordiale

div.head: THE SUCRERIES GO.
CONCORDAT GRANTED.
SATURDAY’S MEETING OF CREDITORS.
div.p: The creditors of the Société des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie o'Egypte met oi Saturday after- noon at 3 o'clock. Judge Tack presided over the meeting, which was held at the Mixed Courts, assisted by MM. Zighara ana Chiarai-oli. Toe principal mere beta of the Cairo Bar were there with the Hon. A. J. Davey, M. Naas, and other members of the company.

At the opening of toe proceedings Me. Carton de Wiart informed the judge that alt the credi¬tors had agreed to accept a slight modification on the proposals already submitted to the Court. M. Zighara then read a letter from Me. Courceiie, *ho protested most spiritedly against the gianting of the concordat preveuttf and demanded the prosecution of all the directors except the Hon. A. J. Davey.

However, as Me. Conroeile only represented 85 shares the majority swept his protest aside, end Me carton de W lart laid before the' Coart the minutes of the arrangement adopted as to the concordat with the signatures of the credi¬tors, and with it the oonvcntiou of the Daira Sugar Compauy and the Suoiertes.
The voting followed, with this result : for the granting uf the cunoordat, 64,2x5 votes, representing L. E. 2,267,11s ; against, 199 votes, representing In E. 4
Tue yroce't verbal was signe i at 6 p. m. and the Sucreries Company opened a new chapter in its history. May it end happily.
The confirmation of the arrangement will take place on Saturday next

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Pasteur Institute.
The Government has appointed a German bacteriologist, Dr. Ernest Meinicke, to manage the Pasteur Institute at Cairo.
The late King of Denmark.

Tue Dead March in •‘haul” was played at St. Mark’s and All Saints' Churches, and the flag at the British Consulate floated half-mast high yesterday as it was the day of the funeral of King Christian IX.
Boy Drowned.

Our Suet Correspondent writes: — last Thursday, owing to the southerly gale at Suet, three lighters laden with coal sunk, one if which, in the Bitter Lake, turned over, and a native boy was drowned. His body was not yet been recovered.
Cairo’s New Bridge.

The Abba, Bridge will have a drawbridge in the centre for the passage of vessels. But there will i e a footbridge, which will allow pedestrians to cross even when the draw bridge is up, as is the case the Tower Bridge in London.
Custom House Porters’ Cate.

We are asked to correct the statemen which appeared under the above heading on Thursday. Mr. Stagni ie not in litigation with the Custom House Porters’ Society but with the Socite de seoour mutuel de Portefaix d'Altxandne (i.e., the Town Porters’ Society;-

Our Suez Correspondent writes: — Lest Thursday, owing to the southerly gale at Sues, three lighters laden with coal sunk, one of which, in the Bitter Lake, turned over, and a native boy was drowned. His body was not yet been recovered.
Cairo's New Bridge.

The Abbas Bridge will have a drawbridge in the centre for the passage of vessels. But there will be a footbridge, which will allow pedestrians to cross even when the draw bridge is up, as is the case with the Tower Bridge in London.
Custom House Porters' Case.

We are asked to correct the statesmen which appeared under the above heading on Thursday. Mr. Stagnt is not in litigation with the Custom House Porters’ Society, but with the Societe de secour mutual de Portefaix d’Alexandrie (i.e., the Town Porters’ Society).
Hellenic Diplomatic Agency.

During the aoseuce ot the Helleuio Di¬plomatic: Agent M. rekalis, the secretary t. the consulate, will be acting Consul-General. It is rumored that M, Geunadis, the Cunsu.- General, will be appointed secretary to Prince George in Crete, as he has a thorough knowledge of the affairs of that island.
Egyptian Bronzing & Metal Colouring Co., Ltd.

This company wits registered on January 26 with a capital of £ 0,000 in £1 shares (7,0oi preference). (Inject, to an quire and tarn ti account a certain process for oxidising, bronzing, and metal colouring, and with a view there to adopt an agreement with J. P. Haden, W. N. Haden, C. L. Haden, and D. 0. Moody. Ho initial public issue. The first directors (to number not less than three nor more than five) are W. N. Haden, C. L. Haden, and D. O. .Moody and E. V. Mitchell. Qualification, 6 shares. Remuneration (except managing director) as fixed by the company.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company

Three Sailings a-Week.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
WHERE HAVE THEY GONE ?
MYSTERIOUS DEPARTURE OF VESSELS.
(FROM ODE CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Suez, Saturday.

Yesterday evening the Coast Guard cruiser Nour-el-Bahr sailed from Suez for an unknown destination, and was followed by the British cruiser Diana It is supposed that they have both gone up the Gulf of Akaba
The Akaba negotiations are officially stated to be proceeding most amicably, and a favorable solution of the frontier difficulty is anticipated within the next few days.
Naoum Bey 8hukair, of the Intelligence Department, has left for Sinai.

div.head: THE CAB STRIKE.
div.p: At the extraordinary meeting of the Alex¬andria Municipal Commission held on Satur¬day afternoon, it was decided to adopt the new cab tariff proposed by the andria committee appointed to deal with the question, but the proposed reduction of the tax im¬posed on oab8 was not agreed to. It is, bow ever, believed that the question of 'he tax will be farther discussed at the next municipal meeting, after the elections.

div.head: SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: On almost every occasion that we report the weekly Saturday evening’s dance at the Savoy Hotel, we have to record a larger attendance than ever. Last Saturday, both dining-room and restaurant were filled to overflowing before the dance, and later in the evening an excep-tionally large number of residents came to swel the throng Dancing was, of course, considerably interfere 1 with as the ball room was un¬comfortably crowded. but at the Savoy the larger crowd is the greater is the merriment, and the bumps and jostling’s pass unheeded. Those who did not dance formed bridge parties or found chairs in the bill-room from which to watch the more youthful "tread the light fantastic,” and the evening was enjoyed by one and all.

Among the some four hundred present were Mr. and Mrs. Cranston, Mr, Mrs., and Miss Smart Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, the Mi sea Coles, Dt. and Mrs. Armstrong, Mrs. Freeman, Mr. and Miss R per, Lady and Miss Hemming, Mr. Randolph Berens, Miss de Vahl, Miss ffrenob, Major Owen Bey, Miss Sidney Boulter, Vfrs. Valentine Smith, Miss Arab idge, Mr. Temple,Mrs. Aston Shepherd, Mr. J.P. Taylor, Mrs. and Miss Nungovioh, Mrs. Will, Mr. G. M. Taylor, Mr. Bilmski Mr. Reid, Dr. Brabant, Mr. Storer, Mr. and Mrs. Crookshank Pacha, Mr. and Mrs. Amster. Mrs. and the Misses York, Mr. Moberley, M-. Kenneth Speire, Miss Limpson, Mr. Grundy. Mrs. and Miss Levendge, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Mre El-wo-'h. Mra. Melville. Mrs. Bayl-y, the Mieses Hurley, Mrs. and Miss Crofron, Mr. W. Ward, Dr. Graff, Sir J ihn and Lady Ro era Pacha, Captain and Mrs. Rome, Sir James and the Misses Blyth, the Mis«es Pell, Mr. C. div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL
div.p: There is no diminution in the popularity of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel dances, and in spite of the extra one on Tuesday night, and that given by Mrs. Crofton on Wednesday, the rooms were filled again to their utmost on Thursday, on which evening alone close on four hundred people sat down to dinner in the hotel The usual dinner patties were in progress, many tables being laid for fourteen, sixteen, and eighteen guests, and among the hosts that evening were the Princes Louis and Antoine d’Orleans, who have returned to Cairo and taken up their quarters at Ghezireh, Sir James Blyth, Lady Keyser, Mrs. Hardy, Col. Gordon, Lady Warner, Mr. and Mrs. Bellamy Storer, Lady Lampson, Co'. Co lingwood, Major Hessey. the Hon. F. Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Cranston, and Mr Johnston.

In the ball-room later on were noticed Princess Radzivill, Lady Smiley with her son, Capt. Smiley, and his wife, Lady Mande, Col. Watson Pasha. Col. Sparkes, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Smart, Mr. Randolph Berens. Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Miss de Vahl, Miss ffreneb, Capt. and Mrs. Bailey, Mrs. and Miss Allan Joseph, Miss Ing, Miss Leveridge, Mrs. Valentina Smith, Miss Ambridge, Mrs. snd Miss Crofton, Miss Lampson, Messrs, de Bilinski, Miss Boulter, Mr. and Mrs. Soott Dalgleish, Lady and Miss Hemming, the Misses Hurley, and many others.

Time forbids any special notice of the many pretty frocks worn on this occasion, but on every count the evening proved a most successful one, and there were numerous expressions of regret when the programme came to an end

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries S.S. Portugal, from Mar eilles, passed the Straits of Messina on SatURDay and is due here to-morrow.
The Moss liner Tabor sailed hence on Saturday afternoon, for Liverpool, v a M lta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,484 bales cotton,

div.head: THE NATIONAL BANK
div.p: NO GOVERNOR APPOINTED
CHITTY BEY DECLINES THE POST.

The final selection of a new Governor of the National Bank of Egypt has still to be made, r for Chitty Bey has declined to accept the post. (After the Egyptian Government had agreed I to accept the selection of the board of directors d it was universally considered a foregone conclusion that the man whom they had chosen as their candidate would be appointed, and great was the amazement yesterday when it was known that the Director General of Customs o ha 1 intimated on Saturday afternoon that he r did not wish to accept the moat remunerative ii position in Egypt. The grounds on which Chitty Bey has based his refusual is that he has had I no experience of banking business and that he ii therefore does Dot consider that he can conscientiously accept the management of the E moat important banking concern in the country.

The reason for his selection as their candidate by the board of directors was that during his tenure of office as head of the greatest revenue-earning department in Egypt, he had shown great powers of administration and organization, and had in every way given proofs that he was possessed of the exceptional , abilities necessary for the guidance of the “ bank. Another point which carried great weight with the board in making their choice was that he was a man of iron fixity of purpose, so that if he had made up his mind that a certain course was the right one, he would not deviate from it a hair's breadth notwithstanding what powerful influences might be brought to bear on him from the City.

The selection if Chitty Bey by the board re¬presented the collective judgment of the most competent set of business men in Egypt, for the directors include the cream of he commercial and financial intelligence of the country. When such practical men as Boghos, Pacha Nubar, Baron Jacques de Menasce, Messrs. Aghion, Beyerle. Foster, de Tschndi, Cattaui, Suares, Zervudachi. Rollo, Ralli, Benachi, Salvago. Milton, and Pelazaeus decided to choose the Director-General of Customs so as their candidate, it was the highest tribute n that oonld be paid to his character and capacity.

At the interview which took place at the British Agency this day week between Lord Cromer and the directors, it was, however, decided that advice from London should be, sought, but on Friday morning the Egyptian Government announced that it would not g abide by this decision and was quite willing “ to same to accept the candidate of the hoard. The waiver on the part of the Egyptian Government was tantamount to Lord Crmar's endorsement of the directors choice, and consequently everybody expected that a final decision would be arrived at when the board, met on Saturday afternoon. When it was known therefore yesterday morning that Chitty Bey had intimated his in willingness to accept the post all the qnidnoncery of Cairo and I Alexandria, who had already begun to speculate as to who would be the new head of the Customs, had to start on a fresh trail; but the search for motives which would induce he rennroiation of the most lucrative billet in Egypt nonplussed the boldest in a country whose prosperity engenders only the most sordid ideals.

Besides the magnificent salary, the L.E. 1 000 house allowance, and the annual remuneration of L E. 1,200 and L.E. 500 for the chairmanships of the Agriculture and Abyssi¬nian Bank", there are other lucrative per¬quisites attached to the governorship. per example, after the 4 percent. to the share¬holder, and 10 per cent, to the reserve on original profile, there is 10 percent. which goes to the board, of which the Governor first takes 25 per cent. L.E. 10,000 went to the board, he took LE 2,500 before the board came in, and then came in himself far the balance with the rest of the beard as a director. There are of course plenty of other legitimate ‘‘pickings,” even if extraneous directorships are henceforth prohibited, and the total annual income will come not far from L.B. 10,000.

When a man who is only, in receipt of LE. 1.500 a year refuses such a post on the grounds of lank of qualification when it is spontaneous¬ly offered to him, the imagination of the aver¬age person is at a loss to account for such a situation. Especially is this so in Egypt, where lack of experience has never been considered a disqualification and we have English officials placed in positions requiring most technical knowledge who have never received any professional training. For instance, one of the moat important posts in the Ministry of Justice is held by an official who has had no legal training whatsoever, and there are many other instances of favourites of fortune who have been jockeyed into positions without any quali¬fications.

The decision of Cbitty Bey is to he respectes’. He bolds that it is the primary and principal qualification of a banker to be well acquainted with banking, for it is a business which is not learned in a day, but needs antitude end ap¬prenticeship like any other calling. Of banking Chitty Bey, from practical experience, admit-tedly knows nothing. Therefore, according to the Egyptian precedent, “lucus a non Iucendo,” so usual in the bestowal of office in Egypt, the choice of the Government and of the board of directors has fallen upon him. To some his refusal of such a position will be incomprehen¬sible. To others it will be explicable on the grounds that he lacks the most conspicuous mark of genius, the faculty of rising to the occasion. But to a minority his decision will be received with respect as a memorable sample of scrupulousness in a country where such a virtue is by no means conspicuous.
A meeting of the directors of the National Bank took place on Saturday afternoon, but no decision as to who should be selected as Governor was arrived at.

Our native contemporary “A1 Moavad.” in notifying Chitty Bey’s action, remarks, “In any care he is one of the most useful Englishmen in Egypt, and Egyptians will be glad to see him always holding high positions, which bring him in touch with natives and where his service are useful to the country, whether he holds* post within or without the Government

div.head: INTERESTING BANQUET
div.p: AT SHEPHEARD'S
PRESS ENERTAIN OWEN BEY

The members of the Egyptian Press who recently visited the Sudan gave a dinner to Owen Bey on Saturday evening at 8hepheard’s Hotel. ID spite of the fact that thirteen sat down to table owing to the absence of Naoum Bey 8hakair, the best of good spirits and cordiality prevailed, and the excellent menu provided speedily appeased the qualms of the most superstitious. The health of the guest of the evening was proposed by M. R. C. Canivet, up from Alexandria for the occasion. in one of those neatly felicitous after time speeches that few but a Frenchman can make. Dr. Paris Nimir made an admirable speech in the highest of Arabic. and Tadros Bey Shenouda also proposed the health of Owen Bey in eloquent terms.

In replying to the toasts in his honour Owen Bey, after thanking the Press for their good wishes, and complimenting them on the excellent articles that had been evoked by their visit, stated that every official, Egyptian, Sudanese, and British, would be glad to know that their work had been appreciated by disinterested observers, and that the members of the Press had thoroughly appreciated their visit to the Sudan and the efforts of the Sudan Government to make their visit a pleasant one.

More speeches followed. Mr. Tite, to whose kindness the Press are greatly indebted, replied in a few cordial words to a well-deserv¬ed toast by Dr. Nimr. Owen Bey prop sad “The Press” in a well oho«en and interesting speech, to which Mr. Hafiz Awad and Mr. Graves replied, the former pointing out that from the point of view of the Press the journey to Khartoum had been an unmixed benefit, bringing to/ether representatives of all shades of opinion who were united in their desire to advocate the good of Egypt. After thanking Owen Bey for his toast he called upon all pre¬sent to drink to the proipen-y of the larger unity of the Nile Valley. It was not till after 11 p.m. that the party dispersed after a de-lightful evening.
The Press representatives present were Dr. Paris Nimr, Tadros Bey Shenouda, Hafiz Eff. Awad, Ali Bey Kamel, M. R Ganivet, the Count de Collalto, MM. Camel, Manse. Mans¬field, di Pompeo and Graves.

div.head: EGYPTI AN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LIMITED.
div.p: The report f the diree’oraof this oomnany for the period ending 31stDecember, willbesnbm’t- ted to the shareholders at the seoond "'di ry general meeting to be held at Wim-hes'er H nre, 0 d Broad Street, London, on Thursday next. The report and statement of accounts embrace the period sinoe the incorporation of the company on the 9th of January, 1905, to the 81st Deoember. 190V The operations of the period under review have resulted in a nett profi' (without including any of the apprecia¬tion on investments referred to below) of £8 987 2 0. From this the directors have decided to write off one third of the preliminary expenses, amounting to £2.622 7 9, leaving a balanoe at oredit of profit and loss of £6,364 14 3. The directors recommend that this balance be dealt with as follows—In pay¬ment of a dividend of 10 per cent, free of income tax on the paid-op capital - f the com¬pany, £50,000, leaving £1,364 14 3 to be carried forward.

It has not been deemed necessary to set aside anything for reserve, as the investments made by the company represent an appreciation (which does not appear in the accounts submitted, of £10,000 on the basis of a valua-tion taken at practically the lowest point touched during the recent crisis on the Egyptian Bourse, since when prices have recovered considerably. The flotation of two important companies, the Building Lands of Egypt, Limited, and the Associated Cotton dinners of , Egypt, Limited, has been carried out and the success which has already attended the operations of these two companies has justified the expectations of the directors. A good return has been obtained from the | discounting of local paper, and a considerable extension of this branch of the company’s business is in contemplation. The company’s ' position has been kept liquid, as its invest¬ments are all readily realisable. Various proposals likely to prove sources of revenue are under consideration. A commercial branch has recently been inaugurated at Alexandria . for the conduct of an import and export business which will be prepared to act as agents for British and other firms who desire a responsible I and active agent in Egypt. Since the statutory ( meeting Major C. H. Villiers and Mr. F. Owen p have resigned their seats on the board. Sir Ernest Cable, during the greater part of his - absence in India, has been represented on the i board by Mr. C. Stewart Cox, who has recently 1 been elected to a seat on the |board, and the shareholders are asked to confirm his appoint-

div.head: NAVAL NEWS
div.p: (from our Correspondent)
Suez, Saturday.
The Russian first-class cruiser Gromoboi arrived at Suez this morning from the far East, and will enter the Canal tomorrow for Port Said
Suez, Sunday

Yesterday forenoon, shortly atter the arrival of be Russian cruiser Gromoboi. her sister ship Ros a arrived. Ro’h cruisers entered the Canal 7 o’clock this morning. These ships belonged to the Vladivostok qradron, and participated in several engagements
H. M. S. King Alfred sailed from SUEZ yesterday evening bound for China,

div.head: CAIRO FESTIVITIES
div.p: BATTLE OF FLOWERS
AN IMMENSE GATHERING

Last night Cairo spent its time endeavoring get rid of the confetti collected during the f afternoon at the “Bataille de Fleurs.’’ Ghezireh 1 still is laid deep in the rainbow-tinged snow- e storm that filled the air during the fray, and t there are but few out of the population who | did not add their quota to the display. Every arahieh in the place must have-been busy conveying the merry-makers across the river, and neither love nor money were able to secure a conveyance for the return journey.

Though the procession was advertised to commence at three o’olock, many people were in their seats soon after two, and a steady and ever-increasing stream of all sorts and conditions followed on their steps, till every seat in every stand and loge was filled, and the course was bordered on either side by a gaily-dressed crowd of men, women, and children, which almost put the decorations even 1 out of conceit with themselves. The confetti and flower sellers did a roaring trade, and when their stock was all run out, the enter¬prising Arab gathered up the fragments off the sandy paths, stuffed them again into discarded bags, and reaped a second harvest. From a strictly impartial view it cannot said that the display of decorated carriages could be compared with those to be seen on the Riviera, or indeed anywhere in France during the carnival season, and as a matter of fact there were many who said the display, was not up to the avenge for Cairo, and was inferior even to that of last year. The most, beautiful carriage, and it really was a work of art, was that belonging to Omar Bey Sultan. It represented a huge basket of pure white, with a high arched handle from, which depended long streamers of snowy chiffon. Both handle and basket and its stand were adorned with white flowers, and on it were perched a crowd of white-feathered, doves. The horses, too, were white, and so also was the harness with silver mountings. The coachman, beside whom stood the Bey, was also in white, and the sayces, too, were robed immaculately and carried white and flower- bedecked wands in their hands. It was not surprising that this oarriage obtained the pig d’honneur, a handsome silver cup, and M. Ferdinand de Martino gained the grandprix for his motor decorated with wreaths of violets and white flowers. Another carriage, drawn by two horses, was transformed into a veritable kiosk of flowers wherein was enshrined a dainty lady with two charming children in fairy like attire; another motor oar, which gained the second prize and was owned by M. Alexander Comanos, was transformed into the likeness of a scarlet dahabieh wreathed about with flowers, and two tiny children in a gaily- decorated oar drawn by a diminutive donkey ware overcome with pride when presented with a prize banneret. 0 her prizes ware awarded to the three ladies bearing flower-decked' sunshades (Mmea. Z *her, Beriketti, and Innis), I perhaps the prettiest being one with large transparent medallions encircled with dainty wreaths of lilies of the valley, the fragile hat of the Wwearer being made to coreespond

In the procession were many other carriages more or less decorated, and many people pre¬ferred spending their time moving round and round the course to remaining in the stands, and considering the crowd of pedestrians and vehicles it was wonderful that the afternoon passed without mishaps. As for the spirit of carnival, it was there with all its accustomed accessories. The air was filled with confetti and flowers and merry battles ware fought at every corner and ail along the line. Carriages were entangled wtth paper serpentines, while hats and pretty frocks, to say nothing of the garments of the sterner sex, were soon decorated and bespangled with the multicoloured particles

The fun ran riot till confetti bags were finished and the spirits of the throwers exhausted. With dusty throats and spent energies the worn out folk streamed back to the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, where every available nook and cranny was filled with eager tea drinkers. The road back to Cairo was a long procession of vehicles following all the same direction, and though the unfortunate way¬farers had a long and dusty tramp home, the carriage folk did not gain in point of time.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE
div.p: By kind permission of Lt Col. C. J. Mark¬ham and offi'ers, the band of the 1st King's Royal Rifles will perform the following selection of music at the Ghezireh Palace on Tues¬day, 20th inst., from 7.45 to 9.40 p.m., to be followed by an extra small dance :—

1 Spanish Serenade—“La Paloma’—Yradier 2 Flute Solo— “Madrigale”—Simonetti . (Mus. E. Tyler) 3 Selection—^“The Geisha”—Jones 4 Clarinet Solo—“Nocturne”—Chopin (Band Serg. Reynolds) 5 Valse—"Brise dee Nuits’’—Lamothe 6 Selection from the Ballet—“The Dancing Doll”— (by request) Bayer 7 Czardas—“Zsambeki”—(by request) Gung’l 8 Song without Words—“Fruhlingslied”— Mendelssohn Regimental Maroh.—Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King. THOMAS BROWN, Bandmaster.

div.head: OPERA HOUSE FLOODED
div.p: EMPLOYER'S STRANGE FREAK
SATURDAY'S PERFORANCE OFF.

The Cairo Opera House was flooded on Saturday night—not by a thunderstorm but by internal irrigation, the work of an ingenious employ who, doubtless for curiosity’s sake, turned on the fire tape which are designed to play on the stage in case of fire. The streams that descended on the stage should have satisfied and reassured him or any who doubted the value of the precautions now taken against fire, but their volume also alarmed him to such a degree that, paralyzed with tenor, he forgot to turn off the fire main. The scenery, the stage, the orchestra, and many of he properties were drenched, the electrical installation was injured, and the management could only send a frantic appeal to the Ministry of Public Works, who came, saw, and estimated the damages. Consequently there was no per¬formance on Saturday night Iris gave place to Beidckt, and Cairo bad something to talk of.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Horace and Lady Pinching have left on a short trip to Upper Egypt.
Mr. Webb has left Cairo for Assouan on in¬spection

The Hon. F. Morgan, who is staying at pre¬sent at Ghezireh Palace Hotel, had a large dinner party there in one of the sumptuous private dining-rooms on Saturday night. The list of his guests included Sir M. and Lady Mollwraith, Fakhry Pacha, Baron and Baronne de Tranttenberg, Johnston Pacha, Mrs. and Miss Johnston, Vioomte B. de Gironde, Mr. and Mme. T. The following passengers left for the Nile by the S.S. Victoria on Friday last: Mr. 8. K. Humphrey. Mr. and Miss Sohuldt, Miss Adah Blaokwell, Mies Nann Smith, Miss Adeline Smith, Fran Theresa Miioohmeyer, Mr. Domairon, Herr Geheimer Baurath March, Herr Referender Munch, Mr and Mrs. 0. J. Salis¬bury, Mr. 0. J. Salisbury, Junior, Mrs. W. F. Milleck-D, Miss Marion P. Webster, Col. and Mrs. Varney, Miss Mary Augusta, Mrs. Watson, Mrs. Kirklaud Armour Dr. and Mme Petian, Mrs. Walter B. Richards, Miss Adelina Ri¬chards, Herr Dr Numeister, Hen Uhlmann, Mr. and Mrs. von Blumenthal, Mr. Hont von Blumenthal, Misa Nora von Blumenthal, Conntess S. von Onynhaneen, Mr. Alfred la Gaidars, Mrs. Heizfeld, Miss Harriet Gale, Mrs. Hallway, Franlein Rsiohe, Dr. Sverensen, Mr. and Mme da Buisson, Mr. and Mme Tanpin, Mr. and Mme Laglio, Mme de Cordola, Mr. Gaillard, Mr. Harrier, Mr. de Lespinasse, Mile Vulois, Mme Lervy, Mme Delle, Mrs. H. M. Barclay, Baron and Baronne de Saint-Ti ivier, Baron Robert de 8aint-Trivier.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: We regret to learn of the death, which took place at an early hoar this morning, of Mr. Hans von Tschudi, son of Mr. C. von Tschndi, head of the firm of Messrs. Plants & Co., of our town. Deceased was only 20 years of age, and died after a short illness. The funeral will take place to-morrow morning at 9 o’clock from the Deaconesses’ Hospital, Mohrrem Bey. We beg to tender nor sincere sympathies with Mr. and Mrs. von Tschudi in their cruel bereavement

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday
